ST. JOHN'S PRESIDENT-ELECT
If Professor R. V. D. Magoffin accepts the presidency of St. John's
College, the undergraduates of Johns Hopkins will lose one of their best
friends. The genial instructor of archaeology is by far one of the most
popular members of the faculty.
The seniors recently showed their appreciation of Dr. Magoffin's
interest in student affairs by selecting him as the faculty member of
June Week Committee. He is one of that rare variety of professors
• that is as broad of heart as of mind. It is a safe venture to say that
he has a closer understanding of students than any of our faculty members. Most any day he may be found during lunch hour mingling with
the "young hope." The democratic smile and friendly chat will be
missed.
Dr. Magoffin could, probably, work wonders at St. John's; yet
we can hardly help but hope that he will risk the chance of future advancement at Hopkins. Dr. Fell presided over the Annapolis institution for twenty-seven years, if press accounts may be trusted, yet the
college has received a lower rating in the past few years. And if memory serves, the first president of the University of Pennsylvania was
taken from the president's chair at St. John's. If Dr. Magoffin will
eventually attain the position that his personality deserves, we will, with
regret, be willing to part with him. But unless he will be allowed to
place himself and his institution upon the plane where they belong, we
prefer that he will remain with us.
We congratulate Dr. Magoffin on his election. We congratulate
St. John's on her selection, and we further congratulate her if the
Doctor accepts.
Hopkins' loss will be St. Johni's gain!

The "PRACTICAL" Alchemist and
"THEORETICAL" Robert Boyle
HE alchemists wrote
vaguely of "fluids" and
"principles." Copper
was potentially silver.
Rid it of its red color and the
"principle" of silver would assert
itself, so that silver would remain.
With a certain amount of philosopher's stone (itself a mysterious
"principle") a base metal could be
converted into a quantity of gold
a million times as great.
This all sounded so "practical"
that Kings listened credulously,
but the only tangible result was
that they were enriched with much
bogus gold.
Scientific theorists like Robert
Boyle (I62.7-1691) proved more
"practical" by testing matter, discovering its composition and then
drawing scientific conclusions that
could thereafter be usefully and
honestly applied. Alchemists conjectured and died;he experimented
and lived.

ADVANCEMENT OF ELECTIONS
One of our greatest difficulties in student activities has been the
inexperience of the officers, upon assuming their duties at the start
of the year. The executives of the preceding term have usually graduated and the usual errors of the office repeated instead of eliminated.
The Omicron Delta Kappa Society has realized this fact and has,
consequently, been endeavoring for the past few months to have the
time of elections moved up to a date as near the beginning of the second
semester as possible. All of the organizations, with the exceptions of
the Athletic Board and the Student Council, have agreed to elect at
this date.
It is believed that a greater efficiency and a more responsible method
of financing will result. Seniors who hold office have lesser interest in
the financial success of their respective organizations when they realize
that they will not have to worry one way or the other. A junior, however, will aim to protect himself for the ensuing year.
The plan should mean a great improvement.

Boyle's work has not ended.
Today in the Research Laboratories of the General Electric

Much light has there been shed

occur in a vessel in which a nearly
perfect vacuum has been produced.
One practical result of this work
is the vacuum tube which plays an
essential part in radio work and
roentgenology.

ST. JOHN'S PRESIDENT-ELECT
If Professor R. V. D. Magoffin accepts the presidency of St. John's
College, the undergraduates of Johns Hopkins will lose one of their best
friends. The genial instructor of archaeology is by far one of the most
popular members of the faculty.
The seniors recently showed their appreciation of Dr. Magoffin's
interest in student affairs by selecting him as the faculty member of
June Week Committee. He is one of that rare variety of professors
• that is as broad of heart as of mind. It is a safe venture to say that
he has a closer understanding of students than any of our faculty members. Most any day he may be found during lunch hour mingling with
the "young hope." The democratic smile and friendly chat will be
missed.
Dr. Magoffin could, probably, work wonders at St. John's; yet
we can hardly help but hope that he will risk the chance of future advancement at Hopkins. Dr. Fell presided over the Annapolis institution for twenty-seven years, if press accounts may be trusted, yet the
college has received a lower rating in the past few years. And if memory serves, the first president of the University of Pennsylvania was
taken from the president's chair at St. John's. If Dr. Magoffin will
eventually attain the position that his personality deserves, we will, with
regret, be willing to part with him. But unless he will be allowed to
place himself and his institution upon the plane where they belong, we
prefer that he will remain with us.
We congratulate Dr. Magoffin on his election. We congratulate
St. John's on her selection, and we further congratulate her if the
Doctor accepts.
Hopkins' loss will be St. Johni's gain!

"principles." Copper
was potentially silver.
Rid it of its red color and the
"principle" of silver would assert
itself, so that silver would remain.
With a certain amount of philosopher's stone (itself a mysterious
"principle") a base metal could be
converted into a quantity of gold
a million times as great.
This all sounded so "practical"
that Kings listened credulously,
but the only tangible result was
that they were enriched with much
bogus gold.
Scientific theorists like Robert
Boyle (I62.7-1691) proved more
"practical" by testing matter, discovering its composition and then
drawing scientific conclusions that
could thereafter be usefully and
honestly applied. Alchemists conjectured and died;he experimented
and lived.

ADVANCEMENT OF ELECTIONS
One of our greatest difficulties in student activities has been the
inexperience of the officers, upon assuming their duties at the start
of the year. The executives of the preceding term have usually graduated and the usual errors of the office repeated instead of eliminated.
The Omicron Delta Kappa Society has realized this fact and has,
consequently, been endeavoring for the past few months to have the
time of elections moved up to a date as near the beginning of the second
semester as possible. All of the organizations, with the exceptions of
the Athletic Board and the Student Council, have agreed to elect at
this date.
It is believed that a greater efficiency and a more responsible method
of financing will result. Seniors who hold office have lesser interest in
the financial success of their respective organizations when they realize
that they will not have to worry one way or the other. A junior, however, will aim to protect himself for the ensuing year.
The plan should mean a great improvement.
